document.text: W ashington L etter. My lust two letters dealt princi pally with the earnest, nnremitting work in Congress done by the Hon. Henry D. Flood, and I wound up my last letter by promising to give yon a brief outline of the many progressive measures which tbe Member from the Tenth Virginia District has actively advocated, ami which prove beyond shadow of doubt tbat for a long time past he has been entitled to the name of Flood the Progressive. In the first place, I am reminded that Mr. Flood was a strong and active advocate of the Campaign Publicity Bill, which was demanded by all progressive Democrats and by a few progressive Republicans. Under the provisions of tbat Bill, the public would have been inform ed, both before and after election, as to the contributors to any campaign expense fund, the amount of money contributed and how it was spent. The standpatter countered against this Bill by passing a law which went only half way, and which in reality had the effect of locking the door after the horse was stolen. However, the progressives, of which Mr. Flood was and is one, finally attained their end. Then takr the three tariff-revi sion bills passed at the extra session of Congress which met in 1911, the Wood Bill, the Farmers Free- List Bill and the Cotton Bill. Mr. Flood actively and aggressively sup ported those measures, and voted for them at their passage. It will be remembered that the siandpatteis fought hard against those three bills, and that President Taft sided with them. Next came the four tariff-revision bills passed at the regular session of Congress this year,the Wool Bill the Metal Bill, the Chemical Bill and the Sugar Bill. Mr. Flood has aotively and consistently supported these measures, while the standpat ters in the House went to defeat fighting against them, and stood firmly against their passage by the Senate. In the latter body the pro gressive Republicans aided the De mocrats in saving two of the bills,in modified form, joined with the standpatters in killing another, and assisted the Democrats in passing a sugar bill, whioh while entirely dif ferent from the bill passed by the more progressive Honse, was far more in accord with the demands of the people than either the Dingley or the Payne tariff laws. And it should not be forgotten that while in 1911 the reactionaries were routed in both Houfe and Senate by i combination of progressive Demo oratsand Republicans, they were saved by the Presidential veto. W hat finally will happen, this year cannot be fore-told, but thus far the reactionaries have been beaten all along the line, and in every battle, Henry D. Flood has been in the front rank of the Progressives. In the very important matter of the admission of Arizona and New Mexico to the sisterhood of States, the right of the people to frame their own constitutions was vigor ously opposed by the reactionaries, and Progresssive Democrats were forced to accept that position be cause of their inability to mnster a two-thirds vote to over-ride the Presidential veto. The wrong Las been righted, however in America by the people themselves, who latei by an amendment to their State Constitution brought about the adoption of the identical idea that the Progressives in the Honse of Representatives had fought for, and that President Taft had vetoed. Mr. Flood was the author of tbr bill admitting Arizona and New Mexico to statehood, and workei unremittingly to accomplish the re suit to which the Democratic part was pledged, and to whioh the Re publican party had also been pledg ed for years, but whioh they had failed to bring about. Flood created a sensation by reading a letter from Judge George J. Hundley, of Farmville, addressed to the chairman of the Democratic S t a t e Central Committee, charging that Colonel Henry W. Anderson, in an address de livered at Farmville on August 30tb, had expressed himself as ashamed of the star in the United States flag which repre sented the State of Virginia. This astounding disclours fell as a thunder bolt upon the voters of the Fifth District who were present at the speaking. The letter, signed by Judge Hundley, the oldest circuit judge in Virginia, was written under date of September 9th. It was in reply to a communi cation from J. N. Brenaman, secretary of the Democratic State Committee. It reads in full, as follows Office of Geo. J. Hundley, Judge of the Fifth Judicial Cir cuit of Virginia. Farmville, Va , Sept. 9,1921. Hon. J. N. Brenaman, Sect. Democratic Committee, Richmond Va. My dear Mr. Brenaman Yours of the 6 th instant re ceived, and I write you, as ac curately as I can, what occur- at the time of Colonel Ander sons speech at Farmville. I note that you say the incident may be used by the committee. I have no objection to your using it,provided it is not based alone upon my statement, for it has been made public. It was published in the Farm ville Herald, and quoted and commented on by the Lynch burg News. I intended that it should be come buplic property, and that there should be no issue of veracity between him and my self, so I repeated to him what he had said, in the presence of the audience, and asked him if 1 had understood him correctly, and he admitted it. He saidWhen he was in the Balkans, trying to help and uplift those miserable people, he carried on the front of his automobile,the American Flag, and the women and chil dren would ccme up and kiss the flag, but that he was really ashamed to let them do this, for he felt that he was practic ing a fraud upon them, to al low them to kiss a flag having upon it a star representing the State of Virginia whose gov ernment was so unrepublican, so despotic, and so disgraceful as that of the State of Virginia. I waited quietly, until he closed, but before the audience dispersed, called upon him to explain thii.t statement, repeat ing what 1 had understood him to say. He did not deny it, but admitted it, with an awkward attempt to explain and which did not explain at all. I did not discuss anything with him but contented myself with Bay ing, Col. Anderson, there are men here who followed the flag of Virginia for four years in the Givil War, and those who fought for that Flag of ours in France, and shed their blood for it, and I want to say for them, that in all our history, there never has been a time, and there never will be a time, whilst the sun shines, that such a thing, as you have said, could be true of the Star repre senting our glorious old State on the Flag of our Common Country. W ith kind regards and best wishes, I am, Yours sincerely, Geo. J. Hundley. Judge Hundley, who presides over the fifth judicial circuit, is a veteran Virginia jurist and a veteran of the Givil War. He has a son, Lieutenant Robert G. Hundley, who saw service on the fighting front in France. Judge Hundley enlisted first with the Albemarle Howitiers, after which he served with the Fifth Vsrginia Infantry. He resigned from this regiment to enter the cavalry, in which arm of the service he remained until the close of the war be tween the states. He was seriously wounded while lead ing a cavalry charge. Lieutenant Robert G. Hund ley, also a war veteran, spilled bis blood in France in defense of the Stars and Stripes. His record was a brilliant one. He served with Company B., 306th Infantry, 77th Army Division with Company F., 120th Infan try, 30th Division, and with Company B., of the 369th New York. This latter regiment was brigaged with troops in the 161st French Army Divis ion, Fourth French Army. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. It is now represented by Mr. Henry St George Tucker, who is serving his third term. He will be opposed for the nomination by State Senator H. D. Flood, of Appo mattox county, and who is a nephew of Senator Faulkner, of West Vir ginia. Mr. Flood is also distantly related to the Tuckers, bnt kinship does not prevent him from doing all he can to get the nomination. Another strong competitor for the nomination will be State Senator Pink Jones, of Highland county, He is ranked as the ablest man now in the Btate senate, and will make strong fight against Tucker. It also said that State Senator Echols, of Staunton, Mr. Tuckers home town, will be a candidate, and if he comes out there surely will be trou ble for the member from the Tenth. Senator Flood was a warm supporter of Thomas S. Martin, of Albemarle, for United States Senator. In fact, he was one of his managers, while Tucker sympathized with General Lee, and the Martin following, being powerful one in the state, they will naturally do all they can to help Flood to capture the nomination, As there is any chance of Tucker getting the nomination General Fitz- hugh Lee, who lives in the district, will not permit his name to be used in connection with the congressional nomination, bnt if it becomes known that Tucker is about to be knocked out it is more than likely that Gen eral Lee may be brought forward as a compromise man. At any rate, it looks as if there would be a red-hot fight in the Tenth. It is believed that Ex-Congressman Yost will be the Republican nominee in the dis trict this year. It is conceded he can have the nomination if he wants it.

document.text: Prospect Notes. How forcibly are we reminded of the near approach of winter when, sitting by early fires, we hear the howling of the chilling wind as it sweeps down from the ice-bound regions of the Northland. Trunks and boxes are unpacked and winter clothing overhauled ready to meet the frost king when he comes. So with life. In the spring time all seems joyous and bright the air is laded with gladsome song and de licious odors as bird and flower, in .field and forest, make glad the heart of man. Then summer with its fields of ripening grain waving  d the flood of mellow light falling in golden bars accross our pathway. Then fall with its stubble fields, and faded flowers and falliug leaves. How it depresses us I Then we be gin to feel old age creeping upon ns. The harvest time is about passed, faculties are failing, there are silver threads among the jet, and we are conscious that the winter of  old age  is upon ns. May we all be prepared for its coming, looking back over the way whence we have come in full assurance of the blessed  harvest home.
